newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU countries set to attack beef reform proposals.
newsitem.headline: EU countries set to attack beef reform proposals.

text.p: European Union beef reform proposals, designed to cut output after demand plunged due to a public health scare over mad cow disease, are expected to come under fire from farm ministers on Monday, EU officials said.
But they added that no decision could be taken next week because the European Parliament has not yet given an opinion.
"Discussions are likely to be heated and last late into the evening," said one official.
Germany and other major beef producers strongly oppose proposals made by the European Commission on July 30 which they say are unbalanced.

Under the proposals, male cattle of between seven and nine months would be accepted into intervention stores, 1996 and 1997 intervention tonnage ceilings would be raised and ceilings on the number of male cattle receiving the special beef premium would be reduced.
A calf slaughter scheme in Britain and Portugal would be extended to all member states and greater incentives offered for extensive beef production.
Commission officials warned that a 400,000 tonne beef intervention ceiling for 1996 was likely to be exceeded in early October and would have to be raised to stop a market collapse.
But it was uncertain if this could be done without ministerial approval.

The package, which would cost 1.3 billion Ecus ($1.7 billion) in 1997, would be financed by a reduction in compensation payments to cereals and oilseed farmers for income losses due to 1992 production-cutting reforms.
Only Britain, Sweden, Denmark and France support the plan.
Other countries said that strong cereals and oilseeds prices could swing the other way and were opposed to a permanent cut in aid.
